DeregistrationReasonOtherText: The terminal and all equipment have been removed from this location

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
The accidental release prevention and emergency response policies at our facility: 
Keyera is committed to the safety of its workers, the public, and the environment.  Its accidental release policy is an integrated approach, involving employee participation, management practices, written procedures, and training.  This facility complies with NFPA-58 requirements for LP-Gas storage, and it is our policy to adhere to all applicable federal, state, and local laws. If an emergency were to occur, it is our policy to notify the Lordstown Fire Department and request that they respond to the emergency. We also maintain incipient stage fire fighting equipment on site.

A description of our facility and the regulated substances handled: 
This facility is a bulk terminal storing LPG for resale to retail propane dealers.  The facility consists of two 80,000-gallon tanks holding approximately 336,000 pounds each of liquid propane.  Additionally there is a capacity to unload two 30,000-gallon capacity rail cars.  There are both manual and automatic emergency shutdown systems on all LPG equipment at the site.

The worst-case and alternative release scenarios:
Our worst-case scenario is failure of one of the 80,000-gallon storage tanks when the storage tank is filled to the greatest amount allowed (87% at 60F), resulting in a vapor cloud explosion. It assumes all of the propane is released and ignited.  No passive mitigation system is considered.  The resulting distance to the endpoint extends offsite, and public receptors are within the distance to the endpoint.  Keyera has multiple safeguards in place which make this scenario very unlikely.  Our alternative release scenario involves a propane release from a multi-port 2.5 inch relief valve over a 5-minute period at a rate of 863 pounds per minute.  An excess flow check valve is the active mitigation system considered in this scenario.  A total of 4,315 pounds of propane is ignited, resulting is a vapor cloud exp

losion.  This would generate a pressure wave with a minimum 1 psi overpressure extending 0.1 miles.  The resulting distance to the endpoint extends offsite.  In this scenario the only public receptors are within the industrial park.

The general accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps:
This facility complies with EPA?s accident prevention rule, the OSHA PSM standard, and all applicable state and local codes and regulations.  The propane system is designed, installed, and maintained in accordance with NFPA-58 and state law.

Five-year accident history: 
Keyera Energy, Inc. acquired the facility in June 2006.  We have never had an accident involving propane that caused deaths, injuries, property or environmental damage, evacuations, or shelterings in-place.  To the best of our knowledge no such incident occurred prior to acquisition by Keyera Energy, Inc.

The emergency response program:
In the event of an emergency involving our propane system, it is our policy to notify the Lordstown Fire Department and request that they help respond to the emergency.  We also have trained employees in incipient stage fire fighting.  We have coordinated our response plans with the fire department; members of the fire department will be provided the opportunity to visit our facility and inspect our propane storage system.  

Planned changes to improve safety:
Keyera Energy, Inc. will continually strive for safety improvement.  Periodic process safety inspections will be conducted followed with timely response.
